mESSKx-y5.memHandModelNotes: Eastern spotted skunks inhabit bushy, rocky, and wooded areas where they prefer extensive vegetative cover (Kinlaw 1995, Wilson & Ruff 1999). I used edge to get at these habitats. Applied buffer width based on body size/mobility index   Amy Silvano 27jun05.  ****Kennedy & Reed (2000) indicated that in appalachians spotted skunks were taken above 430m. Use this elevation in the Appalachian moutians ONLY elsewhere DO NOT restrict with elevation.

habitat_description:
Spilogale putorius includes the subspecies interrupta, or the plains spotted skunk, formerly referred to as the distinct species S. interrupta.

The species’ habitat requirements have not been thoroughly studied; as recently as 2005, Gompper and Hackett wrote that “Even knowledge of basic habitat preference is superficial; that is, whether the species is forest, prairie, or edge-associated.” Nevertheless, S. putorius has been documented in: palmetto scrub (Howell, 1920; Kinlaw, 1995); mid-elevation forests of oak and hickory with black locust, Virginia pine, and dense understory of wild grape (Bookhout, 1964); heavily grazed riparian cottonwood and willow (Choate et al., 1973); pasture near riparian cottonwoods (Choate et al., 1973); a windbreak of eastern red-cedar (Choate et al., 1973); woodland pasture (Choate et al., 1973); along fence lines, from which the species would make foraging excursions into the surrounding cropland and pasture (Crabb, 1948); wheat fields (Johnson, 1921); Ozark-Ouachita second-growth oak-hickory forest (McCullough and Fritzell, 1984; Hackett et al., 2007; Lesmeister, 2007); Ozark-Ouachita shortleaf pine forest with a hardwood component and a grass/forb understory (Hackett et al., 2007); young shortleaf pine forest with dense understory (Lesmeister, 2007); palmetto thickets on sandy soils (Schwartz, 1952; Kinlaw, 1995); second-growth black oak, white oak, red maple, sassafras, hazelnut, and black gum, with an understory of ferns, mountain laurel, chestnut, and vaccinium spp. (Larson, 1968); and mesic to hydric Appalachian coves with rhododendron and an overstory of eastern hemlock, mountain laurel, white oak, yellow poplar, and black cherry (Reed and Kennedy, 2000).

Eastern spotted skunks den in man-made structures as well as strawpiles, haystacks, firewood piles, junkpiles, hollow trees/logs, rock outcrops, and burrows made by other species (Seton, 1937; Crabb, 1948; Van Gelder, 1959; Choate et al., 1973; Frank and Lips, 1989).

The species avoids forests with open understories (McCullough and Fritzell, 1984; Lesmeister, 2007; Lesmeister et al., 2008; Lesmeister et al., 2010), marshes and semi-aquatic habitats (Kinlaw, 1995), hydric floodplains (Van Gelder, 1959), and open areas with minimal ground cover (McCullough and Fritzell, 1984; Kinlaw, 1995).
